events.comment: Player movement
Dialog choices

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: SpriteMultitouchJoystick
description: Multitouch joysticks are objects showing a joystick on the screen, useful for mobile. They work like a physical gamepad:

- Automatic "mapper" behaviors for 2D and 3D movement behaviors (platformer characters, top-down movement, 3D character etc...). Add one of these to the object with the movement behavior (i.e: the player most of the time) and the behavior will then be controlled automatically by the virtual joystick (it works by reading the multitouch joystick state and simulating controls). No need for additional events to make it work once the behaviors are set up.
There are ready-to-use joysticks in the asset-store [multitouch joysticks pack](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?initial-dialog=asset-store&asset-pack=multitouch-joysticks-multitouch-joysticks).

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: TwoChoicesDialogBoxes
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: A dialog box with buttons to let users make a choice.
description: A dialog box showing multiple options (usually "yes" and "no") and a customizable text message.
It handles keyboard, gamepad and touch controls.

eventsBasedObjects.description: A dialog box showing two options.
eventsBasedObjects.name: TwoChoicesDialogBox

events.comment:
Gamepad, mouse, touch and keyboard are fully supported.
Each action from a device increment or decrement an index that is used to focus the active button, make outlines and trigger a sound effect.
To escape the dialog we can focus the button with the identifier 1 which is usually the button to cancel/deny by pressing one of the key or buttons

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the "Yes" button of the dialog was selected.

The button is clicked
Or
The button is active and a key is pressed to validate the button

The button is clicked
Or

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: PanelSpriteButton
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: A button that can be customized.
description: A button that can be used for menus and most labelled buttons of a game. The button can be customized with a background for each state and a label. It handles user interactions and a simple condition can be used to check if it is clicked.
There are ready-to-use buttons in the asset-store [menu buttons pack](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?initial-dialog=asset-store&asset-pack=menu-buttons-menu-buttons).

changelog.breaking: - Buttons now use "variants", allowing easy swapping of their visual aspect. You will have to make some adjustments to existing buttons in your project. Follow this [migration documentation](https://wiki.gdevelop.io/gdevelop5/objects/custom-objects-prefab-template/migrate-to-variants/) to do these changes.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Bouh
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Gamepads
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Add support for gamepads (or other controllers) to your game, giving access to information such as button presses, axis positions, trigger pressure, etc...
description: Add support for gamepads (or other physical controllers).

- automatic "gamepad mapper" behaviors for 2D and 3D movement behaviors (platformer characters, top-down movement, 3D character etc...). Add one of these to the object with the movement behavior (i.e: the player most of the time) and the behavior will then be controlled automatically by the gamepad (it works by reading the gamepad state and simulating controls). No need for additional events to make it work once the behaviors are set up.
The Bomberman-like example handles 4 players with gamepads ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://goose-bomberman)).

inlineCode: //Define an new private object javascript for the gamepad extension
controllerButtonNames: { //Map associating controller button ids to button names
// "XINPUT" cannot be used to check if it is a xbox controller is just a generic
// name reported in Firefox corresponding to the driver being used by the controller

// Anything smaller than this is assumed to be 0,0

// We're outside the dead zone, but we'd like to smooth
// this value out so it still runs nicely between 0..1.
// That is, we don't want it to jump suddenly from 0 to
//Each time a player press a button i save the last button pressed for the next frame
let gamepad = gamepads[i]; // Get the gamepad of the player
//We have to keep this condition because if the user hasn't plugged in his controller yet, we can't get the controller in the gamepad variable.
for (let b = 0; b < Object.keys(gamepad.buttons).length; b++) { //For each buttons
//Save the state of the button for the next frame.

An zero deadzone value give a total freedom on the angle value.

An zero deadzone value give a total freedom on the angle value.
